title: Cryogenic TEM for Soft-Hard and Liquid-Hard Interfaces in Nanotechnology and Energy Sciences
content: In the study of liquid-hard and soft-hard interfaces [1-3], as well as the reaction interphases in electrochemical energy storage and conversion devices [4-6], cryogenic transmission electron microscopy (cryoEM) emerges as an important technique, offering insights into the chemical and structural arrangements at the nano- and atomic scales. In this talk, I will discuss the applications and technical advancements of cryogenic TEM and its spectroscopies, highlighting their potential in understanding the complex phenomena underlying these interfaces/interphases. By navigating through the complexity of sample preparation, imaging conditions, and data interpretation, we will showcase how these cutting-edge cryoFIB, cryoEM, cryoEELS and cryoET techniques uncover native interfaces/interphases that are otherwise difficult to study, contributing significantly to advancements in nanotechnology and energy sciences. This talk will be presented from a unique perspective, reflecting on how the late Prof. Lena Fitting Kourkoutis profoundly influenced both my personal scientific journey and reshaped the field at large.
